content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.Dental disease in domestic cats is commonly associated with the accumulation of plaque on the teeth. A cat food manufacturer is studying the accumulation of plaque on the teeth of cats from a certain population. The accumulation of plaque is assessed using a fluorescent light technique (<math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where an evaluator reviews images of the cat’s teeth and assigns an overall rating from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with lower values indicating less plaque. A previous study indicates the population distribution of the <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ratings for the teeth of cats is bimodal with mean <math alttext="mu equals 6.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 2.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating, <math alttext="x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>, for random samples of <math alttext="400" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats from the population.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.Dental disease in domestic cats is commonly associated with the accumulation of plaque on the teeth. A cat food manufacturer is studying the accumulation of plaque on the teeth of cats from a certain population. The accumulation of plaque is assessed using a fluorescent light technique (<math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where an evaluator reviews images of the cat’s teeth and assigns an overall rating from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with lower values indicating less plaque. A previous study indicates the population distribution of the <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ratings for the teeth of cats is bimodal with mean <math alttext="mu equals 6.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 2.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating, <math alttext="x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>, for random samples of <math alttext="400" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats from the population.

(b) Calculate and interpret the value of <math alttext="the probability of, x bar is less than 6.41" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover><mo><</mo><mn>6.41</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the question.

The manufacturer conducted a study to investigate whether two dental treats are different in minimizing the accumulation of plaque on the teeth of cats. The manufacturer randomly assigned <math alttext="70" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats from a cat sanctuary to receive one of the two dental treats, with <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving Dental Treat G and <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving Dental Treat H. At the end of the study, an evaluator, who was not aware of each cat’s assigned dental treat, determined the <math alttext="F L T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating for each cat. The two dotplots shown display the results of the study. (c) Based on the dotplots, write a few sentences comparing the distributions of the <math alttext="F L T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ratings for the cats who received Dental Treat G and the cats who received Dental Treat H.

The manufacturer will conduct a hypothesis test to investigate whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that there is a difference between the two population means. Let <math alttext="mu sub G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean <math alttext="F L T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating for all cats similar to those used in the study who could have been given Dental Treat G, and let <math alttext="mu sub H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean <math alttext="F L T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating for all cats similar to those used in the study who could have been given Dental Treat H. The hypotheses for the test are as follows. <math alttext="H sub 0: mu sub G equals mu sub H. H sub a: mu sub G is not equal to mu sub H." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) After examining the two dotplots, the manufacturer is concerned that a condition for the test may not be satisfied. Explain why the manufacturer should not be concerned.

A <math alttext="96 percent" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>96</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence interval for a difference between the population means (Dental Treat G minus Dental Treat H) is <math alttext="negative 2.4 plus or minus 0.95" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.4</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.95</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Based on the confidence interval, what conclusion should the manufacturer make for the hypothesis test? Justify your answer.

(f) Based on the conclusion from part (e), describe, in the context of the study, the type of error (Type <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> or Type <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) the manufacturer might have made, and also describe a consequence of making this type of error.

topic.text: 1.9: Comparing Distributions of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Compare distributions or relative positions of points within a distribution.
